docs.title: DebugMe
docs.text:
A Classic Debugging Technique That Never Gets Old

Printing labeled variable values to STDOUT is one of the oldest and most fundamental debugging techniques in computer science. From the earliest days of programming, developers have relied on simple output statements to understand what their code is doing. While modern debuggers offer sophisticated features like breakpoints and step-through execution, there's something elegantly simple and universally effective about printing variables to see their values in real-time.

**DebugMe** embraces this time-tested approach, making it effortless to inspect local, instance, and class variables with clearly labeled output. Sometimes the old ways are the best ways.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Variable Inspection - Display labeled values of local, instance, and class variables
  • Flexible Output - Customize tags, timestamps, headers, and output destinations
  • Global Control - Enable/disable all debug output via $DEBUG_ME flag
  • Zero Overhead - When disabled, debug blocks aren't evaluated
  • Logger Integration - Works with Ruby's Logger and Rails.logger
  • Call Stack Support - Optionally include backtrace information

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe

name = "Ruby"
version = 3.2
features = [:ractors, :fiber_scheduler]

debug_me { [:name, :version, :features] }

# With a custom tag (shorthand syntax)
debug_me('INIT') { [:name, :version] }
# Equivalent to: debug_me(tag: 'INIT') { [:name, :version] }

Output:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:7
   name -=> "Ruby"
   version -=> 3.2
   features -=> [:ractors, :fiber_scheduler]

docs.title: Why DebugMe?
docs.text: Feature DebugMe puts debugger Labeled output N/A Source location Zero overhead when disabled No code changes to disable Works in production Timestamps N/A

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
gem install debug_me

Or add to your Gemfile:

gem 'debug_me'

docs.title: Module: DebugMe
docs.text: The main module providing debugging functionality.

docs.title: Including the Module
docs.text:
require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe

After including, the debug_me method becomes available in the current scope.

docs.title: Method: debug_me
docs.text:
debug_me(options = {}, &block) → String | nil
debug_me(tag, options = {}, &block) → String | nil

The primary debugging method. Outputs labeled variable values to the configured destination.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Description tag String (Optional) Shorthand for tag: option options Hash Configuration options (see below) &block Block Block yielding variable names to inspect

docs.title: Shorthand Syntax
docs.text:
When the first argument is a string, it's used as the tag option:

# These calls are equivalent:
debug_me(tag: 'INFO') { :status }
debug_me('INFO') { :status }

# Shorthand with additional options:
debug_me('TRACE', levels: 2, time: false) { :data }
# Same as:
debug_me(tag: 'TRACE', levels: 2, time: false) { :data }

docs.title: Options Hash
docs.text: Key Type Default Description tag String 'DEBUG' Label prepended to output time Boolean true Include timestamp strftime String '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%6N' Timestamp format header Boolean true Show source file and line number levels Integer 0 Number of backtrace levels to include skip1 Boolean false Add one blank line before output skip2 Boolean false Add two blank lines before output lvar Boolean true Include local variables (empty block) ivar Boolean true Include instance variables (empty block) cvar Boolean true Include class variables (empty block) cconst Boolean true Include constants (empty block) logger Logger nil Logger instance for output file IO $stdout Output destination

docs.title: Block Syntax
docs.text:
The block should yield one of:

Yield Type Example Description Symbol { :variable } Single variable name Array of Symbols { [:var1, :var2] } Multiple variable names String { 'expression' } Expression to evaluate Array of Strings { ['expr1', 'expr2'] } Multiple expressions Empty {} All variables in scope

docs.title: Return Value
docs.text: Returns the output string if $DEBUG_ME is true, otherwise returns nil.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Single variable
name = "Alice"
debug_me { :name }

# Multiple variables
x, y = 10, 20
debug_me { [:x, :y] }

# Instance variables
debug_me { [:@user, :@session] }

# Class variables
debug_me { [:@@counter] }

# Expressions
debug_me { 'array.size' }
debug_me { ['hash.keys', 'hash.values'] }

# All local variables
debug_me {}

# With options
debug_me(tag: 'INFO', levels: 2) { :data }

docs.title: Global Variable: $DEBUG_ME
docs.text:
$DEBUG_ME → Boolean

Controls whether debug output is enabled globally.

docs.title: Values
docs.text: Value Effect true Debug output is enabled (default) false All debug output is suppressed

docs.title: Behavior When Disabled
docs.text:
When $DEBUG_ME is false:

  • debug_me returns immediately
  • The block is not evaluated
  • No output is produced
  • Zero performance overhead

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
$DEBUG_ME = true
debug_me { :value }  # Outputs debug information

$DEBUG_ME = false
debug_me { :value }  # No output, block not evaluated

docs.title: Environment Variable: DEBUG_ME
docs.text: Controls the initial value of $DEBUG_ME at load time.

docs.title: Supported Values
docs.text: Enable Values Disable Values true false yes no on off 1 0

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Enable debug output
DEBUG_ME=true ruby script.rb

# Disable debug output
DEBUG_ME=false ruby script.rb

docs.title: Constant: DebugMeDefaultOptions
docs.text:
DebugMeDefaultOptions → Hash

The default options hash used when options are not specified.

docs.title: Default Values
docs.text:
DebugMeDefaultOptions = {
  tag:       'DEBUG',
  time:      true,
  strftime:  '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%6N',
  header:    true,
  levels:    0,
  skip1:     false,
  skip2:     false,
  lvar:      true,
  ivar:      true,
  cvar:      true,
  cconst:    true,
  logger:    nil,
  file:      $stdout
}

docs.title: Modifying Defaults
docs.text:
# Change default tag
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:tag] = 'TRACE'

# Disable timestamps by default
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:time] = false

docs.title: Constant: DEBUG_ME_MAX_BACKTRACE
docs.text:
DEBUG_ME_MAX_BACKTRACE → Integer

Maximum number of backtrace levels that can be displayed. Default: 15

docs.title: Standard Output
docs.text:
TAG  [TIMESTAMP]  SOURCE_FILE:LINE_NUMBER
   variable_name -=> value

docs.title: With Backtrace
docs.text:
TAG  [TIMESTAMP]  SOURCE_FILE:LINE_NUMBER
   caller(0) -=>
      file1.rb:10:in `method_a'
      file2.rb:20:in `method_b'
   variable_name -=> value

docs.title: Multiple Variables
docs.text:
TAG  [TIMESTAMP]  SOURCE_FILE:LINE_NUMBER
   var1 -=> value1
   var2 -=> value2
   var3 -=> value3

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: DebugMe provides extensive configuration options through the DebugMeDefaultOptions hash and per-call options. You can configure defaults once for your entire application, eliminating the need to pass options on every call.

docs.title: Including the Module
docs.text: The debug_me method is defined in the DebugMe module. How you include it determines the method's availability:

docs.title: Without Including
docs.text:
Without including the module, use the fully-qualified method name:

require 'debug_me'

DebugMe.debug_me { :my_variable }
DebugMe.debug_me('INFO', levels: 2) { :data }

docs.title: Include at Kernel Level (Global)
docs.text:
Include in Kernel to make debug_me available everywhere in your application:

require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe  # At top level, this includes into Object/Kernel

# Now available globally
debug_me { :anywhere }

docs.title: Include at Application Level
docs.text:
In a Rails application, include in ApplicationController or ApplicationRecord:

# app/controllers/application_controller.rb
class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
  include DebugMe
end

# Now available in all controllers
class UsersController < ApplicationController
  def show
    debug_me { :params }
  end
end

docs.title: Include in Specific Classes
docs.text:
For more targeted usage, include only where needed:

class PaymentProcessor
  include DebugMe

  def process(amount)
    debug_me('PAYMENT') { :amount }
  end
end

class OtherClass
  # debug_me not available here unless using DebugMe.debug_me
end

docs.title: Application-Wide Configuration
docs.text: Configure defaults once so every debug_me call uses your preferred settings.

docs.title: Rails Initializer
docs.text:
Create config/initializers/debug_me.rb:

require 'debug_me'

# Include globally (optional - see "Including the Module" above)
include DebugMe

# Disable in production
$DEBUG_ME = !Rails.env.production?

# Configure defaults for all debug_me calls
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:tag]    = 'MYAPP'
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:logger] = Rails.logger
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:time]   = true
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:levels] = 0

# Or merge multiple options at once
DebugMeDefaultOptions.merge!(
  tag:    'MYAPP',
  logger: Rails.logger,
  header: true,
  time:   true
)

Now every debug_me call uses these defaults:

# Uses tag 'MYAPP', logs to Rails.logger, etc.
debug_me { :user }

# Override specific options when needed
debug_me('PAYMENT', levels: 3) { :amount }

docs.title: Plain Ruby Application
docs.text:
Create a configuration file that's required early:

# lib/debug_config.rb
require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe

$DEBUG_ME = ENV['DEBUG'] == 'true'

DebugMeDefaultOptions[:tag]  = 'APP'
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:time] = true
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:file] = $stderr

# main.rb
require_relative 'lib/debug_config'

# debug_me is now configured and available
debug_me { :starting_up }

docs.title: Default Options
docs.text:
The gem ships with these default settings:

DebugMeDefaultOptions = {
  tag:       'DEBUG',                    # Label prepended to output
  time:      true,                       # Include timestamp
  strftime:  '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%6N',    # Timestamp format
  header:    true,                       # Show source file and line
  levels:    0,                          # Backtrace levels to display
  skip1:     false,                      # Skip 1 blank line before output
  skip2:     false,                      # Skip 2 blank lines before output
  lvar:      true,                       # Include local variables
  ivar:      true,                       # Include instance variables
  cvar:      true,                       # Include class variables
  cconst:    true,                       # Include class constants
  logger:    nil,                        # Logger instance
  file:      $stdout                     # Output destination
}

docs.title: tag (String)
docs.text:
The label prepended to each debug output line.

debug_me(tag: 'INFO') { :status }
# INFO  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:1

debug_me(tag: '>>> CHECK') { :value }
# >>> CHECK  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:1

Shorthand Syntax

You can pass a string as the first argument instead of using tag::

# These are equivalent:
debug_me(tag: 'INFO') { :status }
debug_me('INFO') { :status }

# Shorthand with additional options:
debug_me('TRACE', levels: 3) { :data }

docs.title: time (Boolean)
docs.text:
Whether to include a timestamp in the output.

debug_me(time: false) { :data }
# DEBUG  example.rb:1
#    data -=> "value"

docs.title: strftime (String)
docs.text:
Format string for timestamps (uses Ruby's strftime).

debug_me(strftime: '%H:%M:%S') { :now }
# DEBUG  [12:30:45]  example.rb:1

debug_me(strftime: '%Y-%m-%d') { :today }
# DEBUG  [2025-01-06]  example.rb:1

docs.title: header (Boolean)
docs.text:
Whether to print the header line with source location.

debug_me(header: false) { :value }
#    value -=> 42

docs.title: levels (Integer)
docs.text:
Number of backtrace levels to include in output.

debug_me(levels: 3) { :data }
# DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:1
#    caller(0) -=>
#       example.rb:1:in `method_a'
#       example.rb:10:in `method_b'
#       example.rb:20:in `method_c'
#    data -=> "value"

docs.title: skip1 / skip2 (Boolean)
docs.text:
Add blank lines before output for visual separation.

debug_me(skip1: true) { :step1 }
# (one blank line)
# DEBUG  [...]  example.rb:1

debug_me(skip2: true) { :step2 }
# (two blank lines)
# DEBUG  [...]  example.rb:1

docs.title: Variable Selection
docs.text: These options control which variables are shown when using an empty block (debug_me {}):

docs.title: lvar (Boolean)
docs.text:
Include local variables. Default: true

debug_me(lvar: false) {}  # Skip local variables

docs.title: ivar (Boolean)
docs.text:
Include instance variables. Default: true

debug_me(ivar: false) {}  # Skip instance variables

docs.title: cvar (Boolean)
docs.text:
Include class variables. Default: true

debug_me(cvar: false) {}  # Skip class variables

docs.title: cconst (Boolean)
docs.text:
Include class constants. Default: true

debug_me(cconst: false) {}  # Skip constants

docs.title: file (IO)
docs.text:
The output destination. Defaults to $stdout.

# Output to STDERR
debug_me(file: $stderr) { :error }

# Output to a file
log_file = File.open('debug.log', 'a')
debug_me(file: log_file) { :data }
log_file.close

docs.title: logger (Logger)
docs.text:
A Ruby Logger instance for integration with logging systems.

require 'logger'

my_logger = Logger.new('application.log')
debug_me(logger: my_logger) { :status }

For Rails applications:

debug_me(logger: Rails.logger) { :request_id }

docs.title: Modifying Defaults
docs.text:
You can modify the default options globally:

# Change default tag
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:tag] = 'TRACE'

# Disable timestamps by default
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:time] = false

# Always show 2 backtrace levels
DebugMeDefaultOptions[:levels] = 2

docs.title: The $DEBUG_ME Flag
docs.text:
Control all debug output globally:

$DEBUG_ME = true   # Enable (default)
$DEBUG_ME = false  # Disable all output

When $DEBUG_ME is false:

  • No output is produced
  • The debug block is not evaluated
  • Zero performance overhead

docs.title: Environment Variable
docs.text:
Set DEBUG_ME in your environment:

# Disable debug output
export DEBUG_ME=false

# Enable debug output
export DEBUG_ME=true

Supported values:

Enable Disable true false yes no on off 1 0

docs.title: Development vs Production
docs.text:
# config/initializers/debug_me.rb
if defined?(DebugMe)
  include DebugMe

  $DEBUG_ME = Rails.env.development? || Rails.env.test?

  DebugMeDefaultOptions[:logger] = Rails.logger
  DebugMeDefaultOptions[:tag] = Rails.env.upcase
end

docs.title: Conditional Debugging
docs.text:
# Enable only for specific conditions
$DEBUG_ME = ENV['VERBOSE_DEBUG'] == 'true'

docs.title: Per-Module Configuration
docs.text:
module PaymentProcessor
  def self.debug_options
    { tag: 'PAYMENT', levels: 2 }
  end

  def process(amount)
    debug_me(PaymentProcessor.debug_options) { [:amount] }
    # processing logic
  end
end

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to DebugMe! This guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub
  2. Clone your fork locally:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/debug_me.git
cd debug_me
  1. Install dependencies:
bundle install
  1. Verify the tests pass:
bundle exec rake test

docs.text:
# Run all tests
bundle exec rake test

# Run a specific test file
bundle exec ruby tests/debug_me_test.rb

# Run with verbose output
bundle exec ruby tests/debug_me_test.rb -v

docs.text:
• Follow standard Ruby conventions
  • Use 2 spaces for indentation
  • Keep lines under 100 characters when practical
  • Add comments for complex logic

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Create a feature branch:
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name
  1. Make your changes
  2. Add or update tests as needed
  3. Ensure all tests pass
  4. Commit your changes with a descriptive message

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Push your branch to your fork:
git push origin feature/your-feature-name
  1. Open a Pull Request on GitHub
  2. Fill out the PR template with:
  3. Description of changes
  4. Motivation for the change

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will help you start using DebugMe in your Ruby projects.

docs.title: Shorthand Syntax
docs.text:
Before diving in, note that DebugMe supports a convenient shorthand for the tag option:

# These two calls are equivalent:
debug_me(tag: 'PAYMENT') { :amount }
debug_me('PAYMENT') { :amount }

When the first argument is a string, it's automatically used as the tag. This shorthand works with all other options too:

debug_me('INFO', levels: 2) { :data }
# Same as:
debug_me(tag: 'INFO', levels: 2) { :data }

docs.title: 1. Require and Include
docs.text:
require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe

The include DebugMe statement makes the debug_me method available in your current scope.

Include Options

You can include DebugMe at different levels:

  • Top level (global): Available everywhere in your application
  • In a base class: Available in that class and subclasses
  • In specific classes: Available only where included
  • Not at all: Use DebugMe.debug_me { :var } instead

For Rails apps, set up an initializer to configure defaults once. See Configuration for details.

docs.title: 2. Your First Debug Statement
docs.text:
name = "Alice"
age = 30

debug_me { :name }

Output:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:5
   name -=> "Alice"

docs.title: Single Variable
docs.text:
Use a symbol to inspect one variable:

message = "Hello, World!"
debug_me { :message }

docs.title: Multiple Variables
docs.text:
Use an array of symbols for multiple variables:

x = 10
y = 20
z = 30

debug_me { [:x, :y, :z] }

Output:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:6
   x -=> 10
   y -=> 20
   z -=> 30

docs.title: All Local Variables
docs.text:
Call with an empty block to show all local variables:

first = "one"
second = "two"
third = "three"

debug_me {}

docs.title: Instance Variables
docs.text:
Prefix with @ to inspect instance variables:

class User
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
    @created_at = Time.now
    debug_me { [:@name, :@created_at] }
  end
end

User.new("Bob")

docs.title: Class Variables
docs.text:
Prefix with @@ to inspect class variables:

class Counter
  @@count = 0

  def increment
    @@count += 1
    debug_me { :@@count }
  end
end

docs.title: Expressions
docs.text:
Pass strings to evaluate expressions:

numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
debug_me { 'numbers.sum' }
debug_me { 'numbers.size' }

Output:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:3
   numbers.sum -=> 15
DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123457]  example.rb:4
   numbers.size -=> 5

docs.title: Custom Tag
docs.text:
debug_me(tag: 'INFO') { :status }
debug_me(tag: 'WARN') { :error_count }

docs.title: Without Header
docs.text:
debug_me(header: false) { :value }

Output:

   value -=> 42

docs.title: Without Timestamp
docs.text: debug_me(time: false) { :data }

docs.title: Global Control
docs.text:
$DEBUG_ME = false  # Disable all debug output
$DEBUG_ME = true   # Enable debug output

docs.title: Environment Variable
docs.text:
# Disable debug output
DEBUG_ME=false ruby my_script.rb

# Enable debug output
DEBUG_ME=true ruby my_script.rb

docs.title: Installing via RubyGems
docs.text:
Install directly from RubyGems:

gem install debug_me

docs.title: Installing via Bundler
docs.text:
Add this line to your application's Gemfile:

gem 'debug_me'

Then execute:

bundle install

docs.title: Development Installation
docs.text:
For development purposes, you may want to install with development dependencies:

# Gemfile
gem 'debug_me', group: :development

This ensures the gem is only loaded in development environments.

docs.title: Rails Integration
docs.text:
For Rails applications, add to your Gemfile:

group :development, :test do
  gem 'debug_me'
end

Create an initializer at config/initializers/debug_me.rb:

require 'debug_me'

# Include globally so debug_me is available everywhere
include DebugMe

# Disable in production
$DEBUG_ME = !Rails.env.production?

# Configure defaults for your application
DebugMeDefaultOptions.merge!(
  tag:    Rails.application.class.module_parent_name.upcase,
  logger: Rails.logger,
  time:   true
)

Include Strategies

You have several options for including the module:

  • Global (shown above): include DebugMe at top level makes debug_me available everywhere
  • Controllers only: Include in ApplicationController
  • Models only: Include in ApplicationRecord
  • Specific classes: Include only where needed
  • No include: Use DebugMe.debug_me { :var } anywhere

See Configuration for detailed examples.

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify it works:

require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe

test_var = "Hello, DebugMe!"
debug_me { :test_var }

You should see output similar to:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  irb:3
   test_var -=> "Hello, DebugMe!"

docs.title: Updating
docs.text:
To update to the latest version:

# Using gem
gem update debug_me

# Using bundler
bundle update debug_me

docs.title: Uninstalling
docs.text: gem uninstall debug_me

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text: DebugMe uses Ruby's eval() function to access variables in the caller's context. This provides powerful debugging capabilities but requires careful handling.

docs.title: Understanding the Risk
docs.text:
Critical Security Warning

Never pass untrusted input to debug_me. The gem uses eval() internally, which executes arbitrary Ruby code in your application's context.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
When you call:

user_input = params[:data]
debug_me { user_input }  # DANGEROUS!

DebugMe uses eval() to evaluate the string in the caller's binding. If user_input contains malicious code, it will be executed.

docs.title: Attack Example
docs.text:
# If user_input contains:
user_input = "system('rm -rf /')"

# This would execute the system command:
debug_me { user_input }  # Executes: system('rm -rf /')

docs.title: Do
docs.text:
• Use only with hardcoded variable names
  • Use symbols for variable references
  • Disable in production environments
  • Review code for any user input paths to debug_me
# Safe: hardcoded symbols
debug_me { :my_variable }
debug_me { [:var1, :var2] }

# Safe: hardcoded strings
debug_me { 'object.method' }

docs.title: Don't
docs.text:
• Never pass user input to debug_me
  • Never use variables containing user data as the block content
  • Never use in production with debug enabled
# DANGEROUS: user-controlled input
debug_me { params[:field] }          # Never do this!
debug_me { user.selected_field }     # Never do this!
debug_me { request.headers['X-Debug-Field'] }  # Never do this!

docs.title: Disable Debug Output
docs.text:
Always disable debug output in production:

# config/initializers/debug_me.rb
$DEBUG_ME = false if Rails.env.production?

Or use environment variables:

# Production deployment
DEBUG_ME=false bundle exec rails server

docs.title: Docker Configuration
docs.text: ENV DEBUG_ME=false

docs.title: Heroku
docs.text: heroku config:set DEBUG_ME=false

docs.title: Systemd Service
docs.text:
[Service]
Environment="DEBUG_ME=false"

docs.title: Code Review Checklist
docs.text:
When reviewing code that uses DebugMe, check for:

  • No user input flows into debug_me blocks
  • No dynamic variable names based on external data
  • Production environment has $DEBUG_ME = false
  • CI/CD pipelines set DEBUG_ME=false for deployments
  • No debug_me calls in security-sensitive code paths

docs.title: 1. Use Static Analysis
docs.text:
Consider adding a custom RuboCop rule to detect potentially unsafe patterns:

# Example pattern to flag
debug_me { variable_from_user }

docs.title: 2. Wrap in Development Check
docs.text:
def safe_debug(options = {}, &block)
  return unless Rails.env.development?
  debug_me(options, &block)
end

docs.title: 3. Audit Regular Expressions
docs.text:
Search your codebase for potentially unsafe patterns:

# Find debug_me calls with variables (potential risks)
grep -r "debug_me.*{.*[^:]" --include="*.rb" .

docs.title: 4. Remove Before Deployment
docs.text:
Consider using a pre-commit hook or CI check to warn about debug_me calls:

#!/bin/bash
# .git/hooks/pre-commit
if git diff --cached --name-only | xargs grep -l "debug_me" 2>/dev/null; then
  echo "Warning: debug_me calls found in staged files"
  echo "Consider removing before production deployment"
fi

docs.title: Comparison with Alternatives
docs.text: Method Eval Risk Production Safe debug_me Yes With $DEBUG_ME=false puts No Yes (but noisy) pp No Yes Rails.logger No Yes binding.pry Yes No byebug Yes No

docs.title: Reporting Security Issues
docs.text:
If you discover a security vulnerability in DebugMe, please report it responsibly:

  1. Do not open a public GitHub issue
  2. Email the maintainer directly
  3. Allow time for a fix before public disclosure

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
DebugMe is safe when used correctly:

  1. Only use hardcoded variable names (symbols or literal strings)
  2. Never pass user input to the debug block
  3. Disable in production via $DEBUG_ME = false
  4. Review code for any paths where external data could reach debug_me

Treat debug_me with the same caution you would treat any eval() statement in your codebase.

docs.title: Usage Examples
docs.text: This page provides comprehensive examples of using DebugMe in various scenarios.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
require 'debug_me'
include DebugMe

docs.title: Inspecting Local Variables
docs.text:
def calculate_total(items)
  subtotal = items.sum(&:price)
  tax = subtotal * 0.08
  total = subtotal + tax

  debug_me { [:subtotal, :tax, :total] }

  total
end

Output:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  order.rb:6
   subtotal -=> 100.0
   tax -=> 8.0
   total -=> 108.0

docs.title: Inspecting All Variables
docs.text:
Use an empty block to display all local variables:

def process_order(order_id, customer_id)
  order = Order.find(order_id)
  customer = Customer.find(customer_id)
  status = "pending"

  debug_me {}  # Shows: order_id, customer_id, order, customer, status
end

docs.title: Instance Variables
docs.text:
class User
  def initialize(name, email)
    @name = name
    @email = email
    @created_at = Time.now

    debug_me { [:@name, :@email, :@created_at] }
  end

  def update_email(new_email)
    @previous_email = @email
    @email = new_email

    debug_me { [:@previous_email, :@email] }
  end
end

docs.title: Class Variables
docs.text:
class SessionManager
  @@active_sessions = 0
  @@max_sessions = 100

  def self.create_session
    @@active_sessions += 1
    debug_me { [:@@active_sessions, :@@max_sessions] }
  end
end

docs.title: Constants
docs.text:
class ApiClient
  BASE_URL = "https://api.example.com"
  TIMEOUT = 30
  VERSION = "v2"

  def initialize
    debug_me { [:BASE_URL, :TIMEOUT, :VERSION] }
  end
end

docs.title: Method Calls
docs.text:
users = User.all

debug_me { 'users.count' }
debug_me { 'users.first.name' }
debug_me { 'users.map(&:email)' }

docs.title: Complex Expressions
docs.text:
data = { name: "Alice", scores: [85, 90, 78] }

debug_me { 'data[:name]' }
debug_me { 'data[:scores].sum / data[:scores].size.to_f' }

docs.title: Conditional Branches
docs.text:
def process_payment(amount)
  debug_me(tag: 'PAYMENT START') { [:amount] }

  if amount > 1000
    debug_me(tag: 'LARGE PAYMENT') { [:amount] }
    process_large_payment(amount)
  elsif amount > 0
    debug_me(tag: 'NORMAL PAYMENT') { [:amount] }
    process_normal_payment(amount)
  else
    debug_me(tag: 'INVALID') { [:amount] }
    raise ArgumentError, "Invalid amount"
  end
end

docs.title: Loop Iteration
docs.text:
def process_batch(items)
  items.each_with_index do |item, index|
    debug_me(tag: "ITEM #{index}") { [:item] }
    process_item(item)
  end
end

docs.title: Call Stack Analysis
docs.text:
def method_a
  debug_me(levels: 5) { :location }
end

def method_b
  method_a
end

def method_c
  method_b
end

method_c

Output:

DEBUG  [2025-01-06 12:30:45.123456]  example.rb:2
   caller(0) -=>
      example.rb:2:in `method_a'
      example.rb:6:in `method_b'
      example.rb:10:in `method_c'
      example.rb:13:in `<main>'
   location -=> "here"

docs.title: Ruby Logger
docs.text:
require 'logger'

logger = Logger.new($stdout)
logger.level = Logger::DEBUG

debug_me(logger: logger) { :important_data }

docs.title: Rails Logger
docs.text:
class OrdersController < ApplicationController
  def create
    @order = Order.new(order_params)

    debug_me(logger: Rails.logger, tag: 'ORDER') {
      [:@order, 'order_params']
    }

    if @order.save
      debug_me(logger: Rails.logger, tag: 'ORDER SAVED') { :@order }
      redirect_to @order
    else
      debug_me(logger: Rails.logger, tag: 'ORDER FAILED') {
        '@order.errors.full_messages'
      }
      render :new
    end
  end
end

docs.title: File Logging
docs.text:
debug_log = File.open('debug.log', 'a')

debug_me(file: debug_log, tag: 'TRACE') { :data }

debug_log.close

docs.title: Minimal Output
docs.text:
# Just variable values, no header or timestamp
debug_me(header: false, time: false, tag: '') { :value }

Output:

   value -=> 42

docs.title: Verbose Output
docs.text:
debug_me(
  tag: 'VERBOSE',
  time: true,
  header: true,
  levels: 3,
  skip2: true
) { [:var1, :var2] }

docs.title: Custom Timestamp Format
docs.text:
# Short time only
debug_me(strftime: '%H:%M:%S') { :data }

# Date only
debug_me(strftime: '%Y-%m-%d') { :data }

# ISO 8601
debug_me(strftime: '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S%z') { :data }

docs.title: Environment-Based
docs.text:
# In your application initializer
$DEBUG_ME = ENV['DEBUG_ME'] == 'true'

# Or based on Rails environment
$DEBUG_ME = Rails.env.development?

docs.title: Feature-Specific
docs.text:
DEBUG_PAYMENTS = ENV['DEBUG_PAYMENTS'] == 'true'

def process_payment(amount)
  $DEBUG_ME = DEBUG_PAYMENTS
  debug_me { [:amount] }
  $DEBUG_ME = true  # Reset
end

docs.title: Temporary Debugging
docs.text:
def troublesome_method
  original_state = $DEBUG_ME
  $DEBUG_ME = true

  # Detailed debugging here
  debug_me(levels: 10) { [:all, :the, :things] }

  $DEBUG_ME = original_state
end

docs.title: API Request Debugging
docs.text:
def fetch_user(user_id)
  debug_me(tag: 'API REQUEST') { [:user_id] }

  response = http_client.get("/users/#{user_id}")

  debug_me(tag: 'API RESPONSE') {
    ['response.status', 'response.body']
  }

  JSON.parse(response.body)
end

docs.title: Database Query Debugging
docs.text:
def find_orders(customer_id, status)
  debug_me(tag: 'QUERY PARAMS') { [:customer_id, :status] }

  orders = Order.where(customer_id: customer_id, status: status)

  debug_me(tag: 'QUERY RESULT') {
    ['orders.count', 'orders.to_sql']
  }

  orders
end

docs.title: Background Job Debugging
docs.text:
class ProcessOrderJob < ApplicationJob
  def perform(order_id)
    debug_me(tag: 'JOB START', logger: Rails.logger) { [:order_id] }

    order = Order.find(order_id)
    debug_me(tag: 'ORDER LOADED') { [:order] }

    result = process(order)
    debug_me(tag: 'JOB COMPLETE') { [:result] }

    result
  end
end

docs.title: Middleware Debugging
docs.text:
class DebugMiddleware
  def initialize(app)
    @app = app
  end

  def call(env)
    request_id = env['HTTP_X_REQUEST_ID']
    path = env['PATH_INFO']

    debug_me(tag: 'REQUEST') { [:request_id, :path] }

    status, headers, body = @app.call(env)

    debug_me(tag: 'RESPONSE') { [:request_id, :status] }

    [status, headers, body]
  end
end
